Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: Their timely presence is crucial at a high-stakes proceeding that could determine the case outcome
Story: Tonight is the only evening Mia and I have together before I leave for a week of back-to-back hearings. She’s been looking forward to this—dinner at her favorite place, just us, no distractions. I promised her my full attention, no work calls, no checking emails. But as I’m getting ready, my phone buzzes. It’s a message from my firm: the opposing counsel in tomorrow’s high-stakes case wants to meet tonight to discuss a possible settlement. My presence is crucial; missing it could jeopardize months of work and the client’s future. I stare at my reflection, heart pounding, torn between the warmth in Mia’s eyes when I walk through her door and the weight of my client’s trust. Both need me, both expect me to show up. I can’t be in two places at once, and the pressure is suffocating. I grip my phone, caught in the impossible space between love and duty, knowing that whatever I choose, something important will be left behind.
